dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, hey, have you seen the latest from Lilium? The air taxi folks?

dialogue_turns.text: Oh, yeah, the seven-seater, right? And, like, a huge funding announcement.

dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! They've unveiled this new seven-seat version, which, uh, is pretty wild. And they're going public.

dialogue_turns.text: That's the one. And they're valuing Lilium at a whopping $3.3 billion. It's just, like, insane money.

dialogue_turns.text: For sure. And they're raising, what was it, $830 million total? To fuel this whole bet on electric aircraft.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: For sure. And they're raising, what was it, eight hundred thirty million dollars total? To fuel this whole bet on electric aircraft.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Munich-based startup will raise $830 million through the deal with $380 million from Engles SPAC, and $450 million in private investments in public equity to fuel its bet small electric aircraft can beat the traffic on congested city roads.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, $380 million from Qell and another $450 million in private investments. All to, you know, get this new seven-seater off the ground and launching by 2024.

Lilium said the funds would be used to fund the development and testing of a new seven seat electric aircraft and the launch of commercial operations in 2024.

dialogue_turns.text: 2024! That's, uh, pretty ambitious. Especially considering they scrapped the five-seater version not too long ago, right?

dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The deal comes after Forbes revealed in February Lilium had scrapped plans for a five seat version of its aircraft and flight testing for the new larger air taxi would not start until 2022.

dialogue_turns.text: So there's still a bit to go. But I guess their CEO, Daniel Wiegand, is pretty confident. He was talking about how "transport infrastructure is broken."

dialogue_turns.text: Totally. He sees their electric jet tech as the key to higher-capacity aircraft, lower cost per seat-mile, and, uh, way less noise and emissions.

dialogue_turns.text: Which, you know, is the dream for urban mobility. And it just shows how hot this space is getting. Like, Joby also did a huge reverse merger, right?

Liliums German rival Volocopter also raised $239 million from investors including BlackRock earlier this month, according to Reuters.

dialogue_turns.text: It's a real race. Lilium itself actually joined the unicorn club before this, didn't it? With that $1 billion valuation.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, earlier. And they're already planning these vertiports – landing pads – in Florida, and now they're looking at Europe too.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, earlier. And they're already planning these vertiports - landing pads - in Florida, and now they're looking at Europe too.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Lilium announced plans in January to develop a network of vertiports across Florida with Spanish infrastructure company Ferrovial, which is the owner of Londons Heathrow Airport, and revealed today that it was in talks for a similar network of shuttle landing pads in Europe.

dialogue_turns.text: So it's not just about the planes, it's the whole infrastructure. It's, like, a whole new way to think about getting around.
